Present Value / Future Value
Present Value / Future Value - Help Section

The logic behind this formula is that a dollar today is not worth a dollar tomorrow. For example, if you leave $1000 in the bank for a year, it will be worth more (Future Value). Similarly, when you will receive $1000 a year from now, it is worth less to you now (Present Value).
Present Value of Annuity
Present Value of Annuity - Help Section

The logic behind this formula is that if you receive payments for a number of years, each successive payment is worth less to you because you have to wait for it. Five payments of $5000 for example are not worth $25,000 but less (depending on interest rate applied). This formula calculates how much less the stream of payments is worth.
Present Value of Annuity Due
Present Value of Annuity Due - Help Section

The logic behind this formula is that if you receive payments for a number of years, each successive payment is worth less to you because you have to wait for it. Five payments of $5000 for example are not worth $25,000 but less (depending on interest rate applied). This formula calculates how much less the stream of payments is worth. However, for the Annuity Due, it is assumed that the first payment is made / received today. This means that it is essentially the cash flow today + the present value of the annuity for n-1 years.

Present Value: The value of a one-time cash flow today
Future Value: The future value of the Present Value, grown with cumulative interest for the number of years specified
Interest Rate: The interest / discount rate applied to see how much the Present Value decreases / the Future Value increases by
Present Value: The present value sum of all annual payments discounted for the number of years specified
Future Value: The future value sum of all annual payments with cumulative interest for the number of years specified
Number of years: The number of years that you receive payments, make payments, or grow / discount money for
Number of Periods per year: For interst that compounds (is applied) multiple times a year, it specifies how often in one year an annual interest rate is applied
Cash Flow: The annual cash flow received / made each year for the number of years specified

Bonds: The present Value that a bond is worth today, taking into account both the discounted face value payment and the discounted annuity of the coupon payments.
